New Records: Freddie Freeman was an easy choice for World Series MVP after homering in the first four games.
Key Match Events: Walker Buehler closed out the World Series and shut the door on the New York Yankees as the Los Angeles Dodgers captured a 7-6 victory in Game 5.
Freddie Freeman provided a crucial, two-run single as the Dodgers erased a five-run deficit in the fifth inning.
Blake Treinen recorded seven outs in the sixth inning.
Sacrifice flies by Gavin Lux and Mookie Betts in the eighth inning put the Dodgers in front.
Walker Buehler pitched a scoreless frame to secure the victory.
Freddie Freeman launched a grand, Gibsonian walkoff in Game 1 against the Yankees.
The Dodgers loaded the bases with no outs in the eighth inning, leading to sacrifice flies from Lux and Betts.
Walker Buehler struck out Yankees outfielder Alex Verdugo to end the game.
Post-Match Reflections: Manager David Roberts said, 'I’m sure there’s no asterisk on this one.'

Andrew Friedman, president of baseball operations, stated, 'My ultimate, big-picture goal is that, when we are done, that we’re able to look back and say, ‘That was the golden era of Dodger baseball.’
Shohei Ohtani mentioned the owner's desire to win during his press conference after signing his contract.
Miscellaneous Highlights: This title is the eighth in franchise history for the Dodgers.
The championship validated a $1.4 billion offseason splurge built around Shohei Ohtani and Yoshinobu Yamamoto.
The Dodgers' victory will lead to a parade down Figueroa Street.
The Dodgers' current era started in the spring of 2012 when Mark Walter formed a group to purchase the team.
